comments:
This course is the second term of a two-year sequence designed to integrate real world experiences into various bioengienering science courses.

Students overall felt “the course is a good laboratory course.”  Many students enjoyed it “very much due to the amount of knowledge” acquired.

Students did not directly comment on Dr. Chen’s instruction.

Students overall found the course consumed “much time.” The workload entailed “a lot of preparation” for the labs and “coordinating meeting times” to write lab reports. The course is required for both BSE and BAS majors and is intended for the spring semester of sophomore year.

This course is the second term of a two-year sequence designed to integrate real world experiences into various bioengienering science courses.

Students overall felt “the course is a good laboratory course.”  Many students enjoyed it “very much due to the amount of knowledge” acquired.

Students felt Professor Duorte was “teaching useful information for bioengineering research.” One student commented, “Professor Duorte did a good introduction to the programming language.”

Students overall found the course consumed “much time.” The workload entailed “a lot of preparation” for the labs and “coordinating meeting times” to write lab reports. The course is required for both BSE and BAS majors and is intended for the spring semester of sophomore year.

Second term of a two-year sequence designed to integrate real world experiences into various Bioengienering Science courses. It is required for both BSE and BAS majors. It is intended for the spring semester of Sophomore year.

Overall, students liked this course. Many expressed the idea that they gained a lot from the course; one student said “I learned a huge amount with all of the hands-on experience, and gained a lot of practical knowledge.” The majority of students thought that the lab itself was the best part: “The lab portion of this class is actually pretty interesting and can be quite fun at times.” The writing of the lab report, however, was generally received as difficult.

One student described this course as “one of the most work-intensive courses I’ve [taken] at Penn, but it was quite worth it.” This sentiment was shared by other students; “this course suffered from the large amount of work required.” Because this course is based on group work, sometimes “students are unequal in their expectations, and the workload moves to the person who cares the most.”

This course is the second term of a two-year sequence designed to integrate real world experiences into various bioengienering science courses.

Students overall found the course “really great” and “interesting.”

Students overall felt Professor Dourte helped them gain “practical knowledge” and exposure to “application of bioengineering.”

The majority of students agreed that the course had “large amounts of work required,” with one student commenting that the course was “one of the most work-intensive.”  The course is required for both BSE and BAS majors and is intended for the spring semester of sophomore year.
